fields.description:
Bamboo did not check that the name of a branch in a Mercurial repository contained argument parameters. An attacker who has permission to do one or more of the following:
* create a repository in Bamboo
* edit an existing plan in Bamboo that has a non-linked Mercurial repository
* create or edit a plan in Bamboo when there is at least one linked Mercurial repository that the attacker has permission to use
* commit to a Mercurial repository used by a Bamboo plan which has branch detection enabled
can execute code of their choice on systems that run a vulnerable version of Bamboo Server.

*Affected versions:*
* Versions of Bamboo starting with 2.7.0 before 6.1.6 (the fixed version for 6.1.x) and from 6.2.0 before 6.2.5 (the fixed version for 6.2.x) are affected by this vulnerability. 

*Fix:*
* Bamboo version 6.2.5 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/download].
 * Bamboo version 6.1.6 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/download-archives].



*Acknowledgements*
Atlassian would like to credit Zhang Tianqi @ Tophant for reporting this issue to us.



For additional details see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/6FcGO].
fields.summary: Argument injection in Mercurial repository handling - CVE-2017-14590

fields.description:
It was possible for double OGNL evaluation in FreeMarker templates through Struts FreeMarker tags to occur. An attacker who has restricted administration rights to Bamboo or who hosts a website that a Bamboo administrator visits, is able to exploit this vulnerability to execute Java code of their choice on systems that run a vulnerable version of Bamboo.

*Affected versions:*
* All versions of Bamboo before 6.1.6 (the fixed version for 6.1.x) and from 6.2.0 before 6.2.5 (the fixed version for 6.2.x) are affected by this vulnerability. 

*Fix:*
* Bamboo version 6.2.5 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/download].
 * Bamboo version 6.1.6 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/download-archives].



*Acknowledgements*
Atlassian would like to credit Sebastian Perez for reporting this issue to us.



For additional details see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/6FcGO].
fields.summary: Remote code execution through OGNL double evaluation - CVE-2017-14589

fields.description:
Regarding the "Build Plan Permissions" section of the [Logging in Bamboo| https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/logging-in-bamboo-289277239.html] documentation:

The current Build permissions definition:
{quote}
Build - trigger a manual build, or suspend and resume the plan.
{quote}

This should be updated to include that this level of permission also includes:

* Allows disabling of jobs

Once BAM-18839 is fixed, this should be moved to the Edit permission instead.
fields.summary: Update Bamboo Build level permission definition

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Granting a user "Build" level Build plan permissions allows the disabling of jobs within a plan.

h3. Suggested Solution
Remove ability to disable jobs from "Build" level permission tier and move capability to another tier. Perhaps the Edit permission is more suitable.

h3. Why this is important
The ability to alter the build should be restricted to administrators. Disabling jobs is a difficult-to-detect change to the build and many non-admins have this level of permission. 
 
h3. Workaround 
A manual verification of the build configuration before running the build.
fields.summary: Move ability to enable and disable jobs from "Build" level permission tier

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When queuing builds using the REST API, we have the option to add custom variables. This does not yet exist for deployments.

h3. Suggested Solution
Similar to build queue, add support for Deployment variables in the REST API {{/queue/deployment}} endpoint.

h3. Why this is important
This is used to customize deployments further by setting or overriding deployment variables.
 
h3. Workaround 
Although this is not optimal, the current workarounds would be to either:
* Run the deployments from the UI; or
* Add the [Inject Bamboo variables task|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO0601/Configuring+a+variables+task#Configuringavariablestask-InjectBamboovariablestask] to your deployment and update your variables file for the deployment
fields.summary: Custom Variables in /queue/deployment REST call

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, In Bamboo, there is no support for utilizing Linux based machines for .Net Core builds.
And we have to use a Windows-based machine for the same.

h3. Suggested Solution
Introduce the support for Linux machines as well so that the Bamboo application or remote agent on Linux based machine could be used for the ".Net" core builds. 

h3. Workaround
Use Windows machine, no other workaround available.
fields.summary: .Net Core support for Linux

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Bamboo announced support for NUnit 3.0 in version 5.14. The command line arguments that can be passed to NUnit3-Console for newer versions have changed.
h3. Suggested Solution

Update our NUnit Runner Task to support the newer NUnit3-Console 3.x arguments.
[NUnit Console Breaking Changes|https://github.com/nunit/docs/wiki/Breaking-Changes]

h3. Why this is important
Bamboo integration with NUnit needs to be updated

h3. Workaround
h4. Option 1

Use NUnit 3.0
h4. Option 2

Use a Script task with the following command:
{noformat}
nunit3-console --result=TestResults.xml;format=nunit2 --test=<test>{noformat}
(i) We add {{;format=nunit2}} to the result since Bamboo's NUnit Parser expects results in the NUnit 2.x format.
fields.summary: Support New NUnit Runner Command line parameters

fields.description:
Hi,

On a specific test there is a history which is good. But unfortunately when you click on it, it show history of this test for the selected time frame of the plan summary. Which is not really helpful for sporadic test that fail.

!image-2017-11-13-16-58-17-380.png!

It would be good to have complete history across all build by default or at least having the same drop down menu to select the time frame without going back to plan summary changing time frame and then return to test case history.

Thanks
fields.summary: Change timeframe for test history

fields.description:
h3. Documentation for '/repository/\{repositoryId}/enableAccess' and '/repository/\{repositoryId}/enableCi' says:  "Request body is JSON with one attribute : 
 { enable{color:#FF0000}d{color}: true/false }
" while in fact request body should be: "\{ enable: true/false }"
fields.summary: REST endpoints 'enableCi' and 'enableAccess' have wrong description of request body

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
The REST API documentation has no mention of branches in calls that accept the buildKey parameter, such as [enable/disable plans|https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo/REST/6.2.1/#d2e278]

h3. Suggested Solution
Add a note to specify that the key can be for a "plan or plan branch".

h3. Why this is important
It makes the documentation clearer and unambiguous for all Bamboo users.
fields.summary: Specify branches in REST API documentation

fields.description:
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Configure Bamboo with LDAP
#* {noformat:title=atlassian-user-custom.xml}
<!-- LDAP repository -->
<ldap key="myLdapRepository" name="myActiveDirectory" cache="true">
...
<!-- Default bamboo user repository -->
<hibernate name="Hibernate Repository" key="hibernateRepository" description="Hibernate Repository" cache="true"/>
{noformat}
# Make sure at least one group inside LDAP matches a local group in Bamboo (e.g. bamboo-admin)
# Check if the *Groups field* at http://localhost:8085/bamboo/admin/user/editUser.action?username=<USER> is showing the groups this user has

h3. Expected Results
It shows the groups like when other user repositories are used (Crowd, JIRA, Local)

h3. Actual Results
When editing the user there is no group listed
 !group_missing.png|thumbnail!  !group.png|thumbnail! 

They do not show up for LDAP nor local users when LDAP is enabled.

h3. Notes
If none of the groups inside LDAP matches at least one local group in Bamboo, it's possible to at least add and edit the local groups that users belong to. It takes one group, if there's a single match between the internal user repository and LDAP, users are unable to edit membership with local groups.
fields.summary: Groups field is not populated when LDAP repository is used

fields.description:
In bamboo builds, there is the project/build hierarchy.

 

In bamboo deployments that is lost.  If I have multiple plans under a build project and those plans have deployments then I lose the ability to mirror my project\plan hierarchy in deployments.
fields.summary: Add a level of hierarchy to deployments.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Since Bamboo 6.2, when validation tasks fail due to an exception the stack trace is no longer printed.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
* Remove the dialect property from {{bamboo.cfg.xml}} and restart Bamboo.

h3. Expected Results
Full stack trace is printed in Bamboo logs

h3. Actual Results
Higher level exception message is logged, but no stack trace or underlying cause is logged:
{noformat}
2017-11-01 17:16:47,829 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [lifecycle] Real path of servlet context: D:\atlassian\bamboo-6.2.2\Bamboo\atlassian-bamboo\
2017-11-01 17:16:48,297 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [DefaultBootstrapManager] Running validation tasks
2017-11-01 17:16:48,547 FATAL [localhost-startStop-1] [DefaultBootstrapManager] Validation tests failed: [Cannot create list of validation tests Cannot instantiate upgrade task [com.atlassian.bamboo.upgrade.tasks.validation.BranchKeyStartsWithMastersChainKey]]
2017-11-01 17:16:48,610 FATAL [localhost-startStop-1] [DefaultBootstrapManager] Validation tests failed: Your Bamboo instance could not start because health check failed. Contact Atlassian Support at https://support.atlassian.com
2017-11-01 17:16:48,610 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [lifecycle] Bamboo home directory: D:\atlassian\bamboo_HOME
{noformat}
fields.summary: Lost stack trace visibility when validation tasks fail due to an exception in Bamboo 6.2

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Bamboo runs ALTER statements on startup to drop and re-create indices, as if Hibernate believes the index/constraint is incorrect.
The root cause is that Hibernate doesn't name indexes that back up the constraint it creates but it expects the name of the index to match the name of constraint, which is not the case on Oracle (and hsqldb)
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Add the following row to {{<bamboo-install>/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/classes/log4j.properties}}:
{noformat}
log4j.category.org.hibernate=TRACE{noformat}

 # Add a Notification to a Build Plan
 # Restart Bamboo

h3. Expected Results

Bamboo starts up without updating schema
h3. Actual Results

The below lines are shown in the {{atlassian-bamboo.log}} file, with log level {{DEBUG}} or higher on {{org.hibernate}}:
{noformat}
2017-11-07 11:32:07,532 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [UpgradeLauncher] Updating database schema...
alter table NOTIFICATIONS drop constraint notifications_unique
2017-11-07 11:32:27,061 DEBUG [localhost-startStop-1] [SQL] alter table NOTIFICATIONS drop constraint notifications_unique
alter table NOTIFICATIONS add constraint notifications_unique unique (RECIPIENT_TYPE, RECIPIENT, NOTIFICATION_SET, CONDITION_KEY, CONDITION_DATA)
2017-11-07 11:32:27,204 DEBUG [localhost-startStop-1] [SQL] alter table NOTIFICATIONS add constraint notifications_unique unique (RECIPIENT_TYPE, RECIPIENT, NOTIFICATION_SET, CONDITION_KEY, CONDITION_DATA)
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

Manually rename the indices to match the respective constraints.
fields.summary: If using Oracle DBMS, Bamboo recreates unique contraints on each restart

fields.description:
Some customers would like to use a different storage location/gateway than AWS S3 to store their artifacts.

Could we add capabilities to the artifact handler to allow custom storage gateways such as CEPH?

 

h3. Problem Definition

S3 is the only 'remote' storage location for Bamboo Artifacts

h3. Suggested Solution

Change the 'Bucket Name' field to be a URL, which users can use to point the artifact handler to a custom storage gateway, such as CEPH


h3. Workaround

none known
fields.summary: Allow s3 Artifact Handler to use storage Gateways such as CEPH

fields.description:
Currently, there is only Maven support for Bamboo Specs.  Additionally, according to [BSP-35432|https://getsupport.atlassian.com/servicedesk/customer/portal/10/BSP-35432], there is no way to publish a spec without Maven.  

Why support Gradle?
* Gradle has been the official build tool for Android since 2013. That’s a lot of developers right there!
* Gradle is the official build tool for Spring.
* Gradle is much more actively developed than Maven. In the last 2 years, Maven has had only 3 releases [1], but Gradle has had over 20 [2].
* Gradle actually supports parallel builds and intelligent caching, resulting in HUGE performance wins.

I could easily list more examples. I think it is safe to say that even those in the Maven camp would freely admit that Gradle stands with Maven as the two most popular build tools for Java developers. As such, it would be prudent for Bamboo to support Gradle. I, personally, would go further and say that Gradle is quickly leaving Maven behind.

[1] http://maven.apache.org/docs/history.html
[2] https://gradle.org/releases/
fields.summary: Gradle plugin for Bamboo Specs

fields.description:
h3. Summary

As of today, Bamboo has a module called [Build processor module|https://developer.atlassian.com/bamboodev/bamboo-plugin-guide/bamboo-plugin-module-types/build-lifecycle-plugin-modules/build-processor-module] that allows the user to define custom processes during the build.

Ideally, this feature needs to be extended to deployments too.
fields.summary: Extend the build processor module to cover deployments too.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When running RSS on Windows, the following directories have stale file handlers held by Bamboo/Tomcat :
* {{<bamboo-home>\xml-data\build-dir\serverSide\REPOSITORY_STORED_SPECS\repository-<repo-id>\output\plan}}
* {{<bamboo-home>\xml-data\build-dir\serverSide\REPOSITORY_STORED_SPECS\repository-<repo-id>\output\plan-permission}}

h3. Environment
* Windows
* Bamboo 6.2.2+
* Repository Stored Specs enabled

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Run RSS
# Try to run RSS again

h3. Expected Results
RSS will run successfully

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the Maven output:
{noformat}
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal com.atlassian.bamboo:bamboo-specs-runner:6.2.1:run (default-cli) on project bamboo-specs-generator: Execution default-cli of goal com.atlassian.bamboo:bamboo-specs-runner:6.2.1:run failed: java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException: java.nio.file.AccessDeniedException: C:\bamboo-home\xml-data\build-dir\serverSide\REPOSITORY_STORED_SPECS\repository-<repo-id>\output\<directory> -> [Help 1]
{noformat}
 

h3.Workaround
Remove the File Handles before the next run
fields.summary: Bamboo Repository Stored Specs File Handles on Windows

fields.description:
h3. Summary
All Subversion branch plans are disabled due to network connection issue with Subversion server

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Configure a plan to checkout a Subversion repository
# Create a branch plan for the above plan
# Configure {{Plan Configuration >> Branches}} to delete branch plan if the branch is deleted
# Remove the network connection between Bamboo and Subversion server

h3. Expected Results
Bamboo will display error connecting to Subversion server only

h3. Actual Results
The branch plan is disabled without any connection error.
The below logging is thrown in the atlassian-bamboo.log file:
{noformat}
2017-11-07 19:40:09,385 INFO [12-BranchDetectionBackgroundThread:pool-20-thread-1] [SvnBranchDetector] Path http://localhost:8080/subversion/server2/branches does not exist. Please check configuration of SVN repository. No branches found.
2017-11-07 19:40:09,397 INFO [12-BranchDetectionBackgroundThread:pool-20-thread-1] [ChainBranchManagerImpl] Marking VCS branch branches/test2 of chain branch BAM-SUB0 as removed because its name matches branches/test2
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes
* This problem does not happen in Bamboo 5.15.7. The branch plan will have "Unable to detect changes" error
* Bamboo 6.2.2 database VCS_BRANCH table DETECTED_DELETION_DATE column is filled in with the date of the above logging (eg. 2017-11-07 19:40:09)

h3. Resolution
# Shutdown Bamboo
# Backup database for rollback purposes
# Run the following SQL to remove the deletion date:
{code:sql}
UPDATE VCS_BRANCH SET DETECTED_DELETION_DATE=NULL;
{code}
# Upgrade Bamboo to 6.2.3
# Enable all the disabled branch plans manually
fields.summary: Subversion branch plans disabled due to network issue

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

In the current Bamboo, new users can be actually created with usernames which contain special characters like '@', '_', '.', and '-'. (e.g. "john.smith", "john.smith@example.com")

On the other hand, in case that new users are created with inappropriate characters, the error message is shown as "Usernames can only contain lower case characters and digits." and it didn't refer to the above special characters.

When it comes to groupname, the error message is shown as "Group names can only contain lower case characters, digits, @, _, ., and -".

h3. Suggested Solution

In case that we officially support such special characters like '@', '_', '.', and '-' used in username, we should update the error message appropriately.
fields.summary: Username limitaion is inconsistent with the error message

fields.description:
h4. Background

Amazon have released a new compute-optimised instance type (C5).  Tests from our side have shown a significant compute and I/O improvement.  This would likely yield an improvement on build performance for us, so we are keen to be able to put the new instance type into use.

 

Note that the mounting of additional elastic volume may be impacted by this, as they are natively supporting nvme with this instance type, so dev/sdh and /dev/xvdh may change to something like /dev/nvme0n1p1
h4. Acceptance Criteria
 * AWS C5 instance types are added to the *Instance Type* list
 * Changes to AWS mount points are checked
fields.summary: Add New AWS C5 Instance Types To Elastic Image Configuration

fields.description:
It would be very nice if there was a Recipient Type for the user who ran the build plan. Currently, it doesn't seem like there is a good way to automatically send a notification to the person who ran a build plan.

Use case: Send a notification to the user who ran a build plan when the build has completed.
fields.summary: Add notification "Recipient Type" - User started a build

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

In the current [Tomcat deploy task|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/using-tomcat-with-bamboo-for-continuous-deployment-305759758.html], there is no option to add custom parameters. Eg. There is no option to pass arguments to override certificate check while deploying war to tomcat.

h3. Suggested Solution

Add a text field where we can add custom parameters/arguments that we add via command prompt.

h3. Workaround 
With curl in a [script task|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/script-289277046.html], one can perform the deployment that the Tomcat plugin normally does, as curl allowed us to explicitly switch off cert checks.
fields.summary: Ability to add custom arguments in Tomcat deploy task

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, the Bamboo "Artifact handler" feature stores the artifacts in the path {{<agent-home-directory>/bin/}} by default. So whatever name we specify in the field {{Storage Location}} available under the "Artifact handlers" the directory with the same name will be created and the artifacts are stored under it.

There is no such feature to allow the user to use the custom path relative to the "agent-home" directory as the storage location which will allow him to store the artifacts in the path other than the bin directory.
does not have the option to use custom 

h3. Suggested Solution
Introduce a feature which will allow the user to use the custom path relative to the "agent-home" directory as the "storage location" which will allow him to store the artifacts in the path other than the bin directory.

h3. Workaround
No workaround available.
fields.summary: Use of custom Artifact storage location

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If Bamboo is configured to connect to LDAP server with results more than the LDAP server search limit, there isn't any error thrown

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Configure Microsoft Active Directory to have low MaxPageSize limit by running the following commands in Ntdsutil.exe:
{noformat}
LDAP policies
connections
connect to server <DNS name of server>
q
Set MaxPageSize to 10
Commit Changes
{noformat}
# Add more than 10 users into Active Directory
# Configure Bamboo to connect to Active Directory for user management
# Access {{Administration >> Security >> Users}}

h3. Expected Results
There will be error showing "Sizelimit Exceeded"

h3. Actual Results
Only 10 users listed. No error thrown in the log. 

h3. Notes
Paddle test does not have error too

h3.Workaround
# Increase the search limit
OR
# Configure Bamboo "userSearchFilter" in {{atlassian-user.xml}} file to reduce the number of results
fields.summary: No error when LDAP search limit exceeded

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
We are only able to update EC2 credentials through the Bamboo UI, which would require admins to share the credentials with others in case they need to change

h3. Suggested Solution
Add a REST API endpoint to edit the EC2 credentials for Elastic agents (Access Key, Secret Access Key).
Some plugins can do this for AWS Shared credentials, but not for the Elastic agents configuration
fields.summary: REST API to edit Credentials for Elastic Agents

* Database: MySQL

# Have data in the "COMMIT_FILES" table and "USER_COMMIT" table
# Perform the upgrade to version 6.2.2

Primary key constraint should have dropped on the table "COMMIT_FILES"
Column "LIST_POSITION" is dropped.

Hi,

I have had to modify the XCode plugin to support new requirements for the exportOptions.plist file for version 9. The issue is because a new dictionary value "provisioningProfiles" needs to be specified in order to export successfully, examples of people solving it on other platforms below.

I was sent here by your support system so hopefully somebody can review and apply a fix that will work for all versions (I've got no MacOS environment to test).

The code is hosted on Github so you can have access, unfortunately the git history was lost as SourceTree was not able to pull the codebase: [https://github.com/stevokk/bamboo-xcode-9]

I know you're not officially supporting this plugin, but hopefully by me doing some of the work you can save many others from the hours of head scratching. Let me know if I can assist further in any way.

 

[https://issues.jenkins-ci.org/browse/JENKINS-45509]

[https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45138548/xcodebuild-exportarchive-fails-with-error-locating-signing-assets-failed/46463084#46463084]

 

Thanks

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, we have an option for bulk deleting build plans using the option "REMOVE PLANS" but there isn't any such feature for deleting Deployment Projects in bulk. This is very troublesome for a user as he has to delete the projects one by one manually.

h3. Suggested Solution
Include a feature/option for bulk deleting Deployment Projects like the option "REMOVE PLANS".  
 
h3. Workaround
There isn't any effective workaround for this one except for deleting it manually one by one.
fields.summary: Bulk delete option for deleting Deployment Projects

fields.description:
In our setup we are using jira/bitbucket and bamboo tightly together.
 !image-2017-10-31-09-58-38-692.png|thumbnail! 
With bamboo 6.2 work have been done in order to make project setup easier with the new project level in bamboo.. However there are lot of work to do still I think.

In our setup we cannot share, by default, the projects/deployment projects/linked repositories with everyone. (which are the default settings when creating those, and which typically happens if you give the create permissions to everyone). We want the dedicated "support team" to create the "bare" setup then hand it over to the project teams with the correct permissions set so that data are only shared to the team. (If the team later on changes the permission, we can live with that, at least it should be correct from the beginning.

In our setup each project team will have there own dedicated remote agent running on their server, and we don´t have any local agents on the bamboo server itself...

So looking at the setup for bitbucket, the setup is quite straight forward:
 !image-2017-10-31-09-40-19-498.png!

The support team creates the project, does some inital settings and hands it over to the team, and the team can create their repositories as they want.

However with bamboo the process gets quite complicated with lots of issues going back and forth between the support team and the project team:

!image-2017-10-31-09-42-02-125.png!

Also if the team later on adds a new repository you would have to go through steps 3,5,6,7 again...

Some suggestions to make the above process more simpler:
# Add another level of linked repositories. The current one could be changed to global repositories and be kept as it is. Add another level of "project" repositories which by default are only visible if you have project permissions. By doing so, the project teams can create linked repositories by themselves without (by default) sharing it with other teams. If global repositories are needed (eg to be shared between projects, the support could create those.
# Add another level in deployment project so that you have for example Deployment project -> deployment plan -> environment. By doing so the team can create new deployment plans (without the risk of sharing it to the world), and also the support team can dedicate the remote agent directly to the deployment project. 

By doing the above changes, it won´t be nescessary to go through the support team when a new repository is created in bitbucket. The team would be able to create a linked repository themselves, and also add a new deployment plan. (and their dedicated agent would still be able to build and deploy it since its already been assigned to the project/deployment project.)
fields.summary: Simplify project setup in bamboo

fields.description:
Export Configuration should show progress or at least that it is still working / not finished in UI

the page load in the chrome tab wasn't an obvious way to tell that it is still 'working' and I don't see the .zip growing so its hard to tell if it's stuck or what it's doing
fields.summary: Export Configuration should show progress or at least that it is still working / not finished in UI

fields.description:
when trying view the spec of a plan that has a Docker task with empty credentials, I get this error:
{panel}
Export to Bamboo Spec failed: Docker Push/Pull image task:: Argument username can not be blank.
{panel}
 
 The documentation for the Docker task says: 
 "Leave these credentials empty to use the agent's ~/.dockercfg credentials."

It seems like exporting to spec should support empty credentials.
fields.summary: Username cannot be blank for Docker tasks when exporting to spec

fields.description:
Issue:

People are running customized builds on master which throws off production deploys for  engineers.

 

Solution:

Be able to set the permission for running  a custom builds at the branch level.  Currently you can only set permission on the plan level and there is not a different permission for build vs custom builds.

See [https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/build/]

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Bamboo specs silently fail to get changes from Bitbucket repository.
 This behavior causes the user to blindly try multiple times to set the configuration correctly without feedback.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Follow this tutorial to create the specs [Tutorial: Create a simple plan with Bamboo Specs - Atlassian Documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/tutorial-create-a-simple-plan-with-bamboo-specs-894743911.html]
 # Make sure you are able to send this to Bamboo (using Idea or Eclipse)
 # Create a Bitbucket repository with the project created (adding the folder *bamboo-specs-tutorial*)
 # Configure Bamboo to use this repository for specs form [Enabling repository-stored Bamboo Specs - Atlassian Documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/enabling-repository-stored-bamboo-specs-938641941.html]

h3. Expected Results

The plan will start building configuration changes every time a new coming arrives in the repository configured
 *OR*
 An error will be thrown in the logs or an information will be presented in the UI if the repository does not have the correct format to be loaded by repository specs
h3. Actual Results
 # The plan will not get any changes from that repository.
 # No error will be thrown in the logs
fields.summary: Bamboo specs silently fail to get configuration changes from Bitbucket repository

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, Bamboo's Automatic Branch Creation can be configured to create branch plans for VCS branches that match a given regular expression (regex). However, the same does not exist for deployment triggers, which means that a user will need to manually configure a deployment project to run on successful completion of a particular branch plan.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add a similar regex setting for deployment branches

h3. Why this is important
This is useful for teams who want to automate their build and deploy processes.
 
h3. Workaround 
This will need to be done manually, by changing the Build Plan for the Deployment Project.
fields.summary: Allow Bamboo to define deployment trigger branch with regex

fields.description: Delete the repository cache in Bamboo when the respectively linked repository is deleted.
fields.summary: Remove repository cache of a deleted linked repository (Perforce, Git, etc).
REST API for agent assignment should support application/json content type

fields.description:
Currently in order to delete a plan, one needs to be System Administrator and go to _admin/deleteBuilds.action_ in order to delete a project. 

It should be available for project level admin to delete a project.
fields.summary: As a project admin I want an easy way to delete the project

fields.description:
Currently (as of version 6.2), it is possible to dedicate agents to specific deployment projects, deployment environments, or build plans. However, it would be nice to be able to dedicate agents more generally only for deployment or build plans, without defining specific plans.

*Use-Case*

We are using a setup with several remote agents. We do not use local agents for build plans, because there can be very ressource intense builds that can consume too many resources of the host, which could bring down the Bamboo controller. However, when there are a lot of longer running builds going on, the build queue can be full and deployment jobs need to wait until they can run. This is especially annoying if there are urgent deployments to production required.

Deployment jobs do not consume any significant resources, as they usually only copy deployment artefacts around and trigger remote deploy scripts. Therefore, such deployment plans could easily run on local agents on the Bamboo controllers. To ensure that only deployment plans can run on the local agents, it would be nice to be able to dedicate agents only for deployment plans in general, without having to modify every deployment plan or build plan with agent dedication or custom capabilities.

Thanks a lot for considering.
fields.summary: Dedicated agents only for deployment or build plans

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Release contents list in Bamboo is not Artifact Downloader task aware. All shared artifacts are displayed regardless of Artifact Downloader configuration. Scenario:
# Build plan that has 3 shared artifacts
# Deployment plan where the environments are configured to only download 2 of the shared artifacts
# Release contents list displays all 3 shared artifacts when 1 of the artifacts is technically not part of the release

h3. Suggested Solution
Release contents list should be Artifact Downloader task aware. Since each environment can be configured differently, the list should be separated into each environment if the list is different per environment.

h3. Notes
The release is not necessarily downloading all the artifacts, despite what the release contents is displaying. The deployment log shows that only the configured artifacts are being downloaded.
fields.summary: Release contents list for a Bamboo release is not Artifact Downloader configuration aware (all shared artifacts are displayed)

fields.description:
h3. Summary


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Start a branch build on plan that has a branch
# Once the build starts, the build status icon under the Plan Summary > Branches section will begin spinning


h3. Expected Results
When the build completes, the icon is changed to indicate success/fail

h3. Actual Results
The in progress spinner continues indefinitely

h3.Workaround
Refresh the page manually
fields.summary: Branch build status spins indefinitely

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

When using Repository Stored Specs (RSS) there are a few areas where we can improve the Audit logging.

h3. Steps to reproduce
# Create Repository Stored Specs
# Run the code
# Make small changes
# Run again multiple times, making small changes each time

h3. Expected results
The plan audit log shows only the items that changed

h3. Actual results
h4. We update the audit log with a lot of extra information

After making some small changes to the RSS and the plan running 7 times total, the following shows in the audit log:
{noformat}
23:36, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	Default Job	[@xml:space]	[preserve]	[]

23:36, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	[@xml:space]	[preserve]	[]
23:36, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	bambooDelimiterParsingDisabled	[true]	[]
23:36, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	Default Job	[@xml:space]	[preserve]	[]
23:36, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	Default Job	bambooDelimiterParsingDisabled	[true]	[]
23:36, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	Default Job	[@xml:space]	[preserve]	[]
23:36, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	Default Job	bambooDelimiterParsingDisabled	[true]	[]
23:33, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	Default Job	[@xml:space]		preserve
23:33, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	Default Job	bambooDelimiterParsingDisabled		true
23:33, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	[@xml:space]	[preserve]	[]
23:33, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	bambooDelimiterParsingDisabled	[true]	[]
23:33, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	[@xml:space]	[preserve]	[]
23:33, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	bambooDelimiterParsingDisabled	[true]	[]

23:33, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	bambooDelimiterParsingDisabled	[true]	[]
23:33, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	suspendedFromBuilding	true	false
23:29, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	suspendedFromBuilding	false	true
23:25, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	[@xml:space]	[preserve]	[]
23:25, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	bambooDelimiterParsingDisabled	[true]	[]
23:25, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	[@xml:space]	[preserve]	[]
23:25, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	bambooDelimiterParsingDisabled	[true]	[]
23:25, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	description	Plan created from (enter repository url of your plan)	Yay RSS!
23:22, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	custom.dependencies.trigger.remote.strategy		none
23:22, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	custom.dependencies.triggerOnlyAfterAllStages		false
23:22, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	custom.dependencies.triggerForBranches		true
23:22, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	custom.dependencies.trigger.remote.strategy		none
23:22, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	custom.dependencies.triggerOnlyAfterAllStages		false
23:22, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	custom.dependencies.triggerForBranches		true
23:22, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	[@xml:space]	[preserve]	[]
23:22, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	bambooDelimiterParsingDisabled	[true]	[]
23:22, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	custom.dependencies.trigger.remote.strategy		none
23:22, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	custom.dependencies.triggerOnlyAfterAllStages		false
23:22, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	custom.dependencies.triggerForBranches		true
23:22, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	[@xml:space]	[preserve]	[]
23:22, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	bambooDelimiterParsingDisabled	[true]	[]
23:21, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	[@xml:space]		preserve
23:21, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	bambooDelimiterParsingDisabled		true
23:21, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	Plan has been created.
23:21, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	[@xml:space]		preserve
23:21, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	bambooDelimiterParsingDisabled		true
23:21, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	[@xml:space]		preserve
23:21, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	bambooDelimiterParsingDisabled		true{noformat}
Out of the large block above, we have the following (3/51 lines) that users want to see:
{noformat}
23:33, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	suspendedFromBuilding	true	false
23:29, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	suspendedFromBuilding	false	true
23:25, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	description	Plan created from (enter repository url of your plan)	Yay RSS!
23:21, 20 Oct	SYSTEM	 	Plan has been created.
{noformat}
h4. We repeat the same logs on subsequent runs

If the same code is run multiple times, such as a repository being created, we'll see that line audited for each run, even though the repository already exists.
h3. Suggested Solution

Hide/suppress these extra logs, or allow log levels to be set
h3. Why this is important

Users want to follow the changes made to the plan in the audit log, and this extra detail makes it hard to do so.
h3. Workaround

There is no known workaround at this time.
fields.summary: Improve Repository Stored Specs Audit Logging

fields.description:
Currently, we see the following regions available on Bamboo EC2 Wizard:

{noformat}
1) US East (Northern Virginia)
2) US West (Northern California)
3) US West (Oregon)
4) EU (Ireland)
5) EU (Frankfurt)
6) Asia Pacific (Singapore)
7) Asia Pacific (Sydney)
8) Asia Pacific (Tokyo)
9) Asia Pacific (Seoul)
10) Asia Pacific (Mumbai)
11) São Paulo
{noformat}

Comparing to AWS [Regions and Availability Zones \- Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud|http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/using-regions-availability-zones.html] documentation, there are 3 regions missing:

fields.description:
h3. Documentation
* [Creating a plan - Clone an existing plan|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/creating-a-plan-289276868.html]

h3. Requirements
Permission under the *Plan* will be used as Plan to Clone:
* {color:blue}Clone{color}

Permission under the *Project* in which plan selected will be cloned to
* {color:blue}Create Plan{color} and/or 
* {color:blue}Admin{color}

h3. What gets cloned
Under {color:blue}Plan configuration{color}, the following gets cloned:
* Stages
* Repositories
* Triggers
* Branches (_only configuration but not branches_)
* Permissions
* Notifications
* Variables
* Miscellaneous
fields.summary: (Documentation) Describe which configuration is preserved when cloning a plan

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When using HTTP for Git repositories and no native git binary is installed, Bamboo will use a Java Git implementation (JGit) to perform git commands. If the address for the repository results in a 301 redirect to another location, the git command will fail with an exception.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Remove any native git capabilities
# Create a plan and add a Git repository with a HTTP URL that performs a 301 redirect to an actual repository 
# Add a source code checkout task
# Run the plan

h3. Expected Results
Git commands succeed

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown:
{noformat}
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03	java.lang.RuntimeException: com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException: Cannot fetch branch from 'https://bitbucket.server.com/scm/proj/repo.git' to source directory 'builddir'. https://bitbucket.server.com/scm/proj/repo.git: 301 Moved Permanently
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.executor.RetryingTaskExecutor.rerun(RetryingTaskExecutor.java:141)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.executor.RetryingTaskExecutor.runTask(RetryingTaskExecutor.java:99)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.executor.RetryingTaskExecutor.retry(RetryingTaskExecutor.java:207)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.executor.RetryingTaskExecutor.retry(RetryingTaskExecutor.java:188)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.vcs.task.VcsCheckoutTask.execute(VcsCheckoutTask.java:121)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.task.TaskExecutorImpl.lambda$executeTasks$3(TaskExecutorImpl.java:284)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.task.TaskExecutorImpl.executeTaskWithPrePostActions(TaskExecutorImpl.java:223)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.task.TaskExecutorImpl.executeTasks(TaskExecutorImpl.java:284)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.task.TaskExecutorImpl.executePreparationTasks(TaskExecutorImpl.java:91)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.pipeline.tasks.PrepareBuildTask.call(PrepareBuildTask.java:74)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.build.agent.DefaultBuildAgent.build(DefaultBuildAgent.java:185)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.build.agent.BuildAgentControllerImpl$1.call(BuildAgentControllerImpl.java:120)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.build.agent.BuildAgentControllerImpl$1.call(BuildAgentControllerImpl.java:113)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.variable.CustomVariableContextImpl.withVariableSubstitutor(CustomVariableContextImpl.java:185)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.build.agent.BuildAgentControllerImpl.waitAndPerformBuild(BuildAgentControllerImpl.java:113)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.build.agent.DefaultBuildAgent$1.run(DefaultBuildAgent.java:126)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.utils.BambooRunnables$1.run(BambooRunnables.java:47)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.security.ImpersonationHelper.runWith(ImpersonationHelper.java:26)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.security.ImpersonationHelper.runWithSystemAuthority(ImpersonationHelper.java:17)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.security.ImpersonationHelper$1.run(ImpersonationHelper.java:41)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at java.lang.Thread.run(Unknown Source)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03	Caused by: com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException: Cannot fetch branch from 'https://bitbucket.server.com/scm/proj/repo.git' to source directory 'builddir'. https://bitbucket.server.com/scm/proj/repo.git: 301 Moved Permanently
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.JGitOperationHelper$4.doWithTransport(JGitOperationHelper.java:311)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.JGitOperationHelper$4.doWithTransport(JGitOperationHelper.java:299)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.JGitOperationHelper.withTransport(JGitOperationHelper.java:861)
error	18-Oct-2017 15:58:03		at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.JGitOperationHelper.fetchInternal(JGitOperationHelper.java:299)
{noformat}


h3.Resolution
Option 1:
* Install a native git binary on the agent (Bamboo Server for local agents) responsible for performing the build and ensure a capability has been added for it.

Option 2:
* Change the repository URL to the direct address which does not have a proxy server performing a 301 redirect
fields.summary: JGit cannot follow 301 redirects when performing Git commands

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Incorrect metamodel for a number of generated classes causes error level log messages to be logged upon start-up. There is no actual impact of these errors since the Hibernate feature that is being validated is un-used in Bamboo.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Start Bamboo 6.2.2

h3. Expected Results
No errors.

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-bamboo.log file:
{noformat}
2017-10-18 14:20:19,887 ERROR [localhost-startStop-1] [MetadataContext] HHH015007: Illegal argument on static metamodel field injection : com.atlassian.bamboo.agent.elastic.server.ElasticImageConfigurationImpl_#availabilityZones; expected type :  org.hibernate.metamodel.internal.SingularAttributeImpl; encountered type : javax.persistence.metamodel.CollectionAttribute
2017-10-18 14:20:19,887 ERROR [localhost-startStop-1] [MetadataContext] HHH015007: Illegal argument on static metamodel field injection : com.atlassian.bamboo.agent.elastic.server.ElasticImageConfigurationImpl_#subnetIds; expected type :  org.hibernate.metamodel.internal.SingularAttributeImpl; encountered type : javax.persistence.metamodel.CollectionAttribute

fields.description:
*Problem:*

Bamboo Specs importer imports encrypted variables, which have been encrypted on a different bamboo server (i.e. using a different encryption key). Decryption of such variable fails with an exception, causing that it's impossible to:
 * see the "Variables" tab (and thus deleting the variable),
 * run a build
 * import new version of specs with corrected value 


*Steps to reproduce:*
 * Create a plan with a secret variable (must contain "password" or "secret" in its name).

 
 * View plan as Bamboo Specs to export it to Java. You will see sth like

{code:java}
new Variable("secret", "BAMSCRT@0@0@someencryptedvalue"){code}
 
 * Try importing it on another instance. Import *succeeds*:

{code:java}
2017-10-06 09:56:04,131 INFO [BambooServer] Publishing plan PROJ-PLAN
2017-10-06 09:56:05,958 INFO [BambooServer] Successfully published plan PROJ-PLAN
Result OK: "http://localhost:8085/bamboo/browse/PROJ-PLAN"
{code}
 
 * Try running the plan. Execution fails:
{quote}Error encountered while triggering manual build: io.atlassian.util.concurrent.LazyReference$InitializationException: java.lang.RuntimeException: org.bouncycastle.crypto.InvalidCipherTextException: pad block corrupted

Plan 'PROJ-PLAN' did not start
{quote}

 
 * The removing the plan. It disappears from the UI (as it's marked for deletion), but not from the system:

{noformat}
2017-10-06 10:08:48,742 ERROR [DelayedDeletionThread] [DeletionServiceHelper] Unable to complete delayed deletion: 
java.lang.RuntimeException: org.bouncycastle.crypto.InvalidCipherTextException: pad block corrupted
at com.google.common.base.Throwables.propagate(Throwables.java:160)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.crypto.instance.SecretEncryptionServiceInternalImpl.decrypt(SecretEncryptionServiceInternalImpl.java:137)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.crypto.instance.SecretEncryptionServiceInternalImpl.decrypt(SecretEncryptionServiceInternalImpl.java:109)
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62)
at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498)
at org.springframework.aop.support.AopUtils.invokeJoinpointUsingReflection(AopUtils.java:333)
at org.springframework.aop.framework.JdkDynamicAopProxy.invoke(JdkDynamicAopProxy.java:207)
at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy262.decrypt(Unknown Source)
{noformat}
fields.summary: Bamboo Specs importer accepts variables encrypted with a wrong key

fields.description:
This is a common scenario

A standard build plan runs build, unit test, and run code coverage. 

Then a deployment plan to a development environment is triggered from that build plan.

A bamboo plugin called "after deployment" can then trigger a Smoke and Acceptance Test build plan to run web tests against that envrionment.  

But that is where things grind to a halt. 

How does the Smoke and Acceptance test then trigger a deployment to a QA environment so a that a Regression Test build plan can be run?

Currently there seems to be no way to really provide continuous delivery with Bamboo
fields.summary: Update Bamboo to support continuous delivery

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When exporting a DockerRunContainerTask with Specs, if no ports where mapped, the code generated won't compile.

h3. Environment
Bamboo 6.2.2

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a DockerRunContainerTask.
# Don't map ports for that container. 

h3. Expected Results
Code that compiles (without an extra ".").

h3. Actual Results
Because no ports were mapped, the output of the Specs export will look like this:
{noformat}
 new DockerRunContainerTask()
	.imageName("stuff/things")
	.serviceURLPattern("http://localhost:${docker.port}")
	.containerEnvironmentVariables("FOO=bar")
	.containerCommand("mvn clean test")
	.containerWorkingDirectory("/data")
	.additionalArguments("--memory=\"1024m\"")
	.
	.clearVolumeMappings()
    .appendVolumeMapping("${bamboo.working.directory}", "/data")),
{noformat}
 
h3. Workaround
- If the customer tries to run a detached container, they can map ports to avoid this issue.
- If the customer runs a foreground container (or they don't want to map ports), they will have to manually edit the output of Specs manually.
fields.summary: When exporting a DockerRunContainerTask with Specs, if no ports were mapped, the code generated won't compile.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
While creating a build plan, when a user creates a new plan with a new repository, it will create a linked repository.

h3. Environment
- Bamboo 6.2.2 
- Bitbucket Server 5.4.0

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Connect both Bamboo and Bitbucket Server with an Application Link.
# Create a new plan.
# In the plan creation screen, section "Link repository to new build plan", select "Link new repository".
# Click on "Configure plan".
# Click on "Create".
# Go to the repository tab, click on the repository.

h3. Expected Results
User is able to view and edit the repository.

h3. Actual Results
- The repository appears to be a linked repository.
 
h3.Workaround
# While creating the plan, don't configure any repositories.
# Once the plan is created, go to the Repository tab.
# Create a new repository connection.
fields.summary: Bamboo creates a linked repository when it should create a plan repository
Bamboo creates a linked repository when it should create a plan repository if that repository already exists as a linked repository

fields.description:
We are collaborating with third-party developers on certain projects. Bamboo's recent permission model changes make managing access to builds and deployments much more convenient.

However, all users have access to the reports feature and can see information on all authors and users. This potentially has sensitive information.

It would be beneficial if the reports functioniality could be disabled for certain groups/users.
fields.summary: Ability to hide the Reports feature

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When testing / saving a GitHub repository and there is an underlying issue (for example, you don't enter a username or pass, or XSRF protection causes a 403 Forbidden) that would normally cause a problem to be reported sensibly to the UI, Bamboo will show a NullPointerException + stack trace in the the UI.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# *Plan Configuration > Repositories > Add a GitHub Repository*
# Don't enter any credentials
# Hit Test Connection / Save the repository

h3. Expected Results
Bamboo errors gracefully.

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown to the UI and {{atlassian-bamboo.log}}
{noformat}
2017-10-18 13:57:26,134 WARN [http-nio-8085-exec-14] [BambooRuntimeExceptionMapper] Unexpected error from REST call
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.github.configurator.GitHubServerConfigurator.validate(GitHubServerConfigurator.java:90)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.vcs.configurator.VcsLocationConfigurator.validateForConnectionTesting(VcsLocationConfigurator.java:41)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.configuration.repository.VcsConfigurationHelperImpl.validateVcsConfigurationForConnectionTesting(VcsConfigurationHelperImpl.java:113)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498)
	at com.atlassian.plugin.util.ContextClassLoaderSettingInvocationHandler.invoke(ContextClassLoaderSettingInvocationHandler.java:26)
	at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy285.validateVcsConfigurationForConnectionTesting(Unknown Source)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498)
	at org.springframework.aop.support.AopUtils.invokeJoinpointUsingReflection(AopUtils.java:302)
	at org.eclipse.gemini.blueprint.service.importer.support.internal.aop.ServiceInvoker.doInvoke(ServiceInvoker.java:56)
	at org.eclipse.gemini.blueprint.service.importer.support.internal.aop.ServiceInvoker.invoke(ServiceInvoker.java:60)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:179)
	at org.springframework.aop.support.DelegatingIntroductionInterceptor.doProceed(DelegatingIntroductionInterceptor.java:133)
	at org.springframework.aop.support.DelegatingIntroductionInterceptor.invoke(DelegatingIntroductionInterceptor.java:121)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:179)
	at org.eclipse.gemini.blueprint.service.util.internal.aop.ServiceTCCLInterceptor.invokeUnprivileged(ServiceTCCLInterceptor.java:70)
	at org.eclipse.gemini.blueprint.service.util.internal.aop.ServiceTCCLInterceptor.invoke(ServiceTCCLInterceptor.java:53)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:179)
	at org.eclipse.gemini.blueprint.service.importer.support.LocalBundleContextAdvice.invoke(LocalBundleContextAdvice.java:57)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:179)
	at org.springframework.aop.support.DelegatingIntroductionInterceptor.doProceed(DelegatingIntroductionInterceptor.java:133)
	at org.springframework.aop.support.DelegatingIntroductionInterceptor.invoke(DelegatingIntroductionInterceptor.java:121)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:179)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.JdkDynamicAopProxy.invoke(JdkDynamicAopProxy.java:207)
	at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy991.validateVcsConfigurationForConnectionTesting(Unknown Source)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.rest.resource.RepositoryResource.testConnectionToRepository(RepositoryResource.java:190)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.rest.resource.RepositoryResource.lambda$testConnection$0(RepositoryResource.java:138)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.variable.CustomVariableContextImpl.withVariableSubstitutor(CustomVariableContextImpl.java:185)

h3.Workaround
* Try to solve the underlying cause before saving the repository or testing the connection. This is difficult without knowing the exact nature of the problem. Some tips:
** Ensure credentials are entered and correct
** Ensure the Bamboo Server has outbound internet access to contact GitHub
** If there's a reverse proxy in-front of Bamboo, ensure your reverse proxy settings are configured correct in {{<bamboo-install>/conf/server.xml}}. Here's an  indicator if this is a problem from the application logs:
{code}
2017-10-17 00:09:23,652 WARN [http-nio-8085-exec-19] [XsrfResourceFilter] Additional XSRF checks failed for request: http://localhost:8085/rest/analytics/1.0/publish/bulk , origin: https://bamboo.atlassian.com , referrer: https://bamboo.atlassian.com/admin/configureLinkedRepositories!doDefault.action , credentials in request: true , allowed via CORS: false
{code}
fields.summary: NullPointerException when testing / saving a GitHub repository and there is any underlying problem

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If an elastic agent fails to connect to S3, Bamboo runs a "route" command. However, we often see this fail.
h3. Environment
* Bamboo Elastic Agent

h3. Steps to reproduce
# Start an Elastic agent with an IP outside of the whitelisted range

h3. Expected Results
Agent starts as expected
h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the {{bamboo-elastic-agent.out}} file:
{noformat}
2017-10-17 00:56:09,188 ERROR [main] [ElasticAgentInstaller] Unable to access S3 bucket, dumping the route table:
2017-10-17 00:56:09,188 INFO [main] [ElasticAgentInstaller] Starting [route, -n]
Exception in thread "main" java.io.IOException: Cannot run program "route": error=2, No such file or directory
	at java.lang.ProcessBuilder.start(ProcessBuilder.java:1048)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.agent.elastic.installer.ElasticAgentInstaller.runCommand(ElasticAgentInstaller.java:135)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.agent.elastic.installer.ElasticAgentInstaller.dumpRouteTable(ElasticAgentInstaller.java:125)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.agent.elastic.installer.ElasticAgentInstaller.install(ElasticAgentInstaller.java:84)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.agent.elastic.installer.ElasticAgentInstaller.main(ElasticAgentInstaller.java:199)
Caused by: java.io.IOException: error=2, No such file or directory
	at java.lang.UNIXProcess.forkAndExec(Native Method)
	at java.lang.UNIXProcess.<init>(UNIXProcess.java:248)
	at java.lang.ProcessImpl.start(ProcessImpl.java:134)
	at java.lang.ProcessBuilder.start(ProcessBuilder.java:1029)
	... 4 more
{noformat}

There should be better logging messages to reduce back-and-forth communications between customers and Support Engineers.
fields.summary: Elastic Bamboo failing to run "route" command

fields.description:
In Bambo v5.15.7 "_You can apply a consistent set of permissions to multiple plans with this wizard. Simply select the plans you want to edit and then Specify the permissions you wish to apply._" from *Bulk edit plan permissions* located in {color:blue}Bamboo admininstration >> Overview >> Plans{color} section.

In Bamboo v6.2, *Changes to permissions* described by [Bamboo 6.2 Release Notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/bamboo-6-2-release-notes-938641951.html] introduces multiple changes to permissions to make permissions management more transparent. At the same time, a new set of REST API endpoint have being introduced (https://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-bamboo/REST/6.2.1/) providing more flexibility to set permissions at Project, Plan, Deployment, Environment and Linked Repositories.

However, some effort is required from users to build a script to gather the correct IDs (Project, Plan, Deployment, Environment and Linked Repositories) and to set the permission needed.

Based on that, the feature *Bulk edit plan permissions* (still available in Bamboo above v6.2) could be extended to *Bulk edit Deployment permissions* reducing time and effort users have to expend in such customisation.

h3. Suggestion
*Bulk edit Deployment permissions*, having the option to select if permission(s) will be granted to:
* Deployment project
* Deployment environment

Depending on the Deployment selected, present user with valid permissions to be picked from:
* Deployment project (permission VIEW, EDIT)
* Deployment environment (permission VIEW, EDIT, DEPLOY)

h3. Summary
As for today we have the option to bulk edit plan permissions. It would be useful to have the same option for deployment project permissions. 

h3. Environment
Bamboo 6.2.2
fields.summary: Add bulk edit for deployment project permissions

fields.description:
The [Bamboo API Changes by Version|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOODEV/Bamboo+API+Changes+by+Version] are an important and helpful resource for app vendors conceptually.

This information hasn't been updated for Bamboo 5.15 - 6.2, and given the major version bump and the many notable improvements since 5.14, I would be surprised if there would be zero changes to the public API (and even if so, just stating that in the resp. API change documentation would be very helpful already).
fields.summary: Bamboo API Changes by Version information is missing for 5.15 - 6.2

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Bamboo connectivity between server and remote agent doesn't fully support the http protocol.
h3. Environment

Bamboo 6.2.2.
h3. Workaround
h4. For Bamboo before version 6.9.0

To configure the client URL to use http, you will still have to use the nio/tcp protocol in the client URL. For example:
{noformat}
<property name="bamboo.jms.broker.client.uri">failover:(http://bamboo:80?wireFormat.maxInactivityDuration=300000)?maxReconnectAttempts=10&initialReconnectDelay=15000</property>
<property name="bamboo.jms.broker.uri">nio://0.0.0.0:80?wireFormat.maxInactivityDuration=300000</property>
{noformat}
h4. For Bamboo after version 6.9.0

There's no workaround.
fields.summary: Add support to use the http protocol in ActiveMQ

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Bamboo Docker task is missing an option to load a docker image from a tar file into a local repository.

h3. Environment

Bamboo 6.2.2

h3.Workaround

Use a script tasks. Example:
# Create an artifact download task to download the tar file. 
# Create a docker task to load the file, for example:
{noformat}
docker load --input my_docker_image.tar
{noformat}
# Create docker task to push or run the image.
fields.summary: Include an option to load docker images in the docker task

fields.description:
h3. Steps to reproduce

# Create a plan with a script task with contents similar to:
{code}
ln -sf /dev/stderr my-artifact
{code}
# Configure the job to save "my-artifact" as an artifact.
# Run the plan on a Linux agent.

Note that {{/dev/stderr}} can be replaced by any named pipe (e.g. {{mkfifo my-artifact}}).

h3. Expected result

The build should finish, either
* as a green build with "my-artifact" missing or saved as a 0 byte file, or
* as a red build with an error about being unable to save "my-artifact".

h3. Actual result

Build hangs forever on the log line "Publishing an artifact: my-artifact" until manually stopped.

Once manually stopped, the build goes grey with logs similar to the following:
{noformat}
17-Oct-2017 06:58:57 	com.atlassian.bamboo.build.artifact.S3ArtifactHandler: Unexpected exception
17-Oct-2017 06:58:57 	Unable to publish artifact [test link]: Unable to publish artifact Job artifact: [my-artifact], pattern: [my-artifact] for MYPROJ-MYPLAN-JOB1-123 via com.atlassian.bamboo.build.artifact.S3ArtifactHandler@3e641fa3
{noformat}

h3. Notes

This is disruptive because:
* a hung build ties up an agent, reducing build capacity until noticed and corrected by a human,
* a named pipe could be present inside a directory, and if the directory is being saved as an artifact, the same result will occur (perhaps a more likely scenario than someone actually trying to save a named pipe as an artifact).

It happens both with the S3 and server local artifact handlers. However, in my testing the build could not even be stopped manually when using the server local artifact handler.
fields.summary: Artifact targets that include named pipes cause builds to hang indefinitely

There's no workaround at the moment.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When Bamboo is configured for LDAP authentication, while adding a user to the Global Permissions, after the user types the first few characters of the user to be added, Bamboo fetches all users from LDAP and then filters the list locally rather than performing a search on the LDAP server using the characters that the user entered. This causes performance problems with large directories.
h3. Environment
 * Bamboo 6.2.1
 * LDAP authentication is configured

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Configure Bamboo 6.2.1 for LDAP authentication
 # As an administrator, navigate to the Global Permissions screen
 # Start entering part of the username or name of the user to be added

h3. Expected Results

Bamboo will perform a search on LDAP using the characters that were entered by the administrator as a search filter (for username, e-mail, first name and last name) and then display the results
h3. Actual Results

Bamboo retrieves all users from LDAP and then filters the list locally based on the characters entered by the administrator. 
 If [profiling is enabled in Bamboo|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamkb/how-to-enable-output-of-profiling-data-in-bamboo-logs-785457692.html], {{catalina.out}} and {{atlassian-bamboo.log}} will show many lines similar to the following at the time the administrator performs the search ({{<adminuser>}} in the example below is the username of the administrator and {{<username>}} is the username of a user in LDAP):
{noformat}
2017-10-16 12:50:50,327 DEBUG [ajp-nio-127.0.0.1-8600-exec-1 url:/rest/api/latest/permissi...able-users username:<adminuser> ] [UtilTimerStack$1:196] [3033ms] - com.atlassian.user.impl.ldap.search.page.LDAPEntityPager_preload__(originalQuery= com.atlassian.user.impl.ldap.LiteralFilter@250345a1)
  [0ms] - com.atlassian.user.impl.ldap.repository.DefaultLdapContextFactory_getLDAPContext
  [0ms] - com.atlassian.user.impl.ldap.DefaultLDAPUserFactory_getUser(<username>)
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

You may be able to restrict the number of users by defining a group search filter, but whether that is possible depends on your organizational structure.
fields.summary: Bamboo retrieves all users from LDAP when adding global permissions

fields.description:
I really like the specs and the features it provides, especially for tests that target the Bamboo application.

But I have noticed that the specs are not OSGi or Plugin V2 aware.

Only TaskProperties that are in the package {{com.atlassian.bamboo.specs.*}} are supported in version 6.2.1. SO any third party specs would have to be placed in that specific package.

It currently is also required to deploy these specs in the {{WEB-INF/lib}} directory of the Bamboo installation.

 

I would like to see the Specs implementation using the {{<export />}} defined class to also whitelist the classes it needs. It would also be nice if the specs implementation would be OSGi aware so it can load classes from plugins so we don't need to deploy specs to the lib directory.
fields.summary: Support third-party specs via OSGi

h3. Summary
Script task body jumps back to the top of the page when something is highlighted and users click back into it

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Script task with the contents "echo hello"
# Highlight "echo hello" and scroll down somewhat
# Mouse click anywhere in the script body field again

h3. Expected Results
Scroll position remains where it was.

h3. Actual Results
Scroll position is moved to the very top of the screen.

h3.Workaround
None

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Bamboo doesn't show errors nor messages when a git merge fails, when "Gatekeeper" is enabled.

h3. Environment
- Bamboo 6.2.1.
- Tested with Bitbucket Cloud.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a repository with at least one branch.
# Configure a plan in Bamboo, with Gatekeeper enabled. 
# Force a merge conflict in the branch.
# Run the plan branch build. 

h3. Expected Results
Build failing. Some notification in UI of the cause of the error.

h3. Actual Results
- Build failing. 
- The build is not displayed in the Dashboard in the section "Recently built":
 !Screen Shot 2017-10-13 at 15.50.39.png|thumbnail! 
- No logs for the failed build:
 !Screen Shot 2017-10-13 at 16.23.58.png|thumbnail! 
- Server logs:
{noformat}
2017-10-13 13:46:37,832 INFO [6-DelayedChangeDetectionThread:pool-12-thread-5] [ChainExecutionManagerImpl] Doing the merge before the first stage
2017-10-13 13:46:37,842 INFO [6-DelayedChangeDetectionThread:pool-12-thread-5] [BranchIntegrationHelperImpl] Checking out code from PR1-PL1, revision e866d7809b39b36568d97a6a0b5b07c1c54c5b7d
2017-10-13 13:46:37,843 INFO [6-DelayedChangeDetectionThread:pool-12-thread-5] [BranchIntegrationHelperImpl] and merging code from PR1-PL10, revision b55a90a4df94af45053affec7d3a13d81efc9884
2017-10-13 13:46:38,990 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-13] [BitbucketBuildStatusUpdater] Unable to sent build status update to Bitbucket: POST https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/pdemitrio/plan-git-1/commit/b55a90a4df94af45053affec7d3a13d81efc9884/statuses/build returned a response status of 400 Bad Request
2017-10-13 13:46:39,023 INFO [http-nio-8085-exec-11] [AccessLogFilter] mate GET http://bamboo6212:8085/rest/api/latest/result/status/PR1-PL10-3?expand=stages.stage.results.result&_=1507902393787 75111kb
2017-10-13 13:46:40,498 WARN [6-DelayedChangeDetectionThread:pool-12-thread-5] [ChainExecutionManagerImpl] Merge command error: Auto-merging textfile.txt
CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in textfile.txt
Automatic merge failed; fix conflicts and then commit the result.
2017-10-13 13:46:40,500 WARN [6-DelayedChangeDetectionThread:pool-12-thread-5] [ChainExecutionManagerImpl] Unable to merge PR1-PL10-3 merge result: MergeResultSummaryImpl{integrationStrategy='GATE_KEEPER', mergeState='FAILED', pushState='TO_BE_ATTEMPTED', failureReason='Merge command error: Auto-merging textfile.txt

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Accessing the Global Permission page has NullPointerException if there is a group (that have been deleted) in the permission database

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a group "testgroup" in Crowd
# Configure Bamboo to use Crowd for User Management
# Add this group "testgroup" into Bamboo Global Permission
# Delete this group "testgroup" in Crowd
# Restart Bamboo (or remove Crowd User Management in Bamboo and re-add it) to clear the cache
# Access the Global Permission page

h3. Expected Results
It should work fine without error

h3. Actual Results
There is nothing display in the Group list and a popup window with NullPointerException appear
The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-bamboo.log file:
{noformat}
2017-10-13 21:03:26,481 INFO [http-nio-8085-exec-14] [AccessLogFilter] kahloun.foong GET http://localhost:8085/rest/api/latest/permissions/global/roles?limit=30&start=0&name=&_=1507899806215 602378kb
2017-10-13 21:03:26,483 WARN [http-nio-8085-exec-13] [BambooRuntimeExceptionMapper] Unexpected error from REST call
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at java.util.Comparator.lambda$comparing$77a9974f$1(Comparator.java:469)
	at java.util.TimSort.countRunAndMakeAscending(TimSort.java:355)
	at java.util.TimSort.sort(TimSort.java:220)
	at java.util.Arrays.sort(Arrays.java:1512)
	at java.util.ArrayList.sort(ArrayList.java:1454)
	at java.util.stream.SortedOps$RefSortingSink.end(SortedOps.java:387)
	at java.util.stream.Sink$ChainedReference.end(Sink.java:258)
	at java.util.stream.Sink$ChainedReference.end(Sink.java:258)
	at java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.copyInto(AbstractPipeline.java:482)
	at java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.wrapAndCopyInto(AbstractPipeline.java:471)
	at java.util.stream.ReduceOps$ReduceOp.evaluateSequential(ReduceOps.java:708)
	at java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.evaluate(AbstractPipeline.java:234)
	at java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline.collect(ReferencePipeline.java:499)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.rest.permission.BasicPermissionResource.listGroupPermissions(BasicPermissionResource.java:119)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.rest.permission.GlobalPermissionsResource.listGroupPermissions(GlobalPermissionsResource.java:164)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:497)
	at com.atlassian.plugins.rest.common.interceptor.impl.DispatchProviderHelper$TypeOutInvoker$1.invoke(DispatchProviderHelper.java:169)
	at com.atlassian.plugins.rest.common.interceptor.impl.DispatchProviderHelper$1.intercept(DispatchProviderHelper.java:83)
	at com.atlassian.plugins.rest.common.interceptor.impl.DefaultMethodInvocation.invoke(DefaultMethodInvocation.java:53)
	at com.atlassian.plugins.rest.common.expand.interceptor.ExpandInterceptor.intercept(ExpandInterceptor.java:34)
	at com.atlassian.plugins.rest.common.interceptor.impl.DefaultMethodInvocation.invoke(DefaultMethodInvocation.java:53)
	at com.atlassian.plugins.rest.common.interceptor.impl.DispatchProviderHelper.invokeMethodWithInterceptors(DispatchProviderHelper.java:110)
	at com.atlassian.plugins.rest.common.interceptor.impl.DispatchProviderHelper$TypeOutInvoker._dispatch(DispatchProviderHelper.java:167)
	at com.sun.jersey.server.impl.model.method.dispatch.ResourceJavaMethodDispatcher.dispatch(ResourceJavaMethodDispatcher.java:75)
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes
* The database table ACL_ENTRY still contain the group "testgroup"
* The following query return the list of group in the Global Permission
{code:sql}
SELECT ID,SID 
FROM ACL_ENTRY
WHERE ACL_OBJECT_IDENTITY = 
(SELECT ID FROM ACL_OBJECT_IDENTITY 
WHERE OBJECT_ID_CLASS = 'com.atlassian.bamboo.security.GlobalApplicationSecureObject')
AND TYPE = 'GROUP_PRINCIPAL';
{code}
* This problem happens to other Permission settings too

h3.Workaround
# Run the following SQL query:
{code:sql}
SELECT DISTINCT(SID) 
FROM ACL_ENTRY;
{code}
# Compare it with the group list in {{Administration >> Security >> Groups}}
# Shutdown Bamboo
# Backup database for rollback purposes
# Delete the group data in the table ACL_ENTRY for the group that does not exist anymore, for example:
{code:sql}
DELETE FROM ACL_ENTRY
WHERE SID='xxx' AND TYPE = 'GROUP_PRINCIPAL';
{code}
Replace xxx with the problematic group that does not exist anymore
# Restart Bamboo
fields.summary: NullPointerException in Global Permission or any other New UI in Permission settings
Bamboo Specs should allow to create deployments from plan branches

fields.description:

h3. Summary

All queued builds disappear when agents are disabled and when you enable them back, Bamboo continues building the remaining plans but no builds are shown in the queue.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Put some builds in the queue;
# Hover the mouse over the "Online agents" ;
# Disable all agents;

h3. Expected Results

All agents are disabled but the build plans should remain in the queue.

h3. Actual Results

  !build_queue.gif! 

h3.Workaround
There is no available workaround.
fields.summary: Build queue disappears when all agents are disabled

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, Bamboo only updates the "Revision" in the Build Result Summary if the checkout is done in a Source Code Checkout Task. If checkout is done in a script Bamboo will only report the checkout done in the initial VCS checkout.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add an option for Bamboo to update the VCS revision ID outside of VCS Checkout Tasks.

h3. Why this is important
Working around some limitations, such as Gatekeeper functionality from Jira builds, requires running checkouts and commits in a Script task. This currently reports an old revision.

h3. Workaround 
Depending on your use case, Gatekeeper or Branch Updater _may_ work as a workaround. This does not work when builds are triggered from Jira, since those builds only run the default/master branch.
fields.summary: Allow Bamboo to update Revision if checkout is made via script task mid-Build

fields.description:
It would be nice to be able to create quick filters for the Bamboo build plan dashboard that allow filtering using the project name pattern (using regex).

Currently it's possible to filter by the build plan name pattern or by concrete (existing) projects, but it's not possible to filter for a project name pattern.

!Selection_162.png|width=709,height=381!

 

Use-case: we maintain a lot of different projects in our Bamboo instance that are developed by different teams. We prefix the project names with the two-letter team shorthandle (e.g. "GI - ", "PM - ") in order to have them automatically grouped and ordered in the plan overview. Having the possibility to create quick filters based on project name patterns would provide a very convenient mean for team quick filters to see their projects without the need to add a label to every single build plan, which is often forgotten and puts even more configuration burden on the developers.
fields.summary: [Quick Filters] Allow to filter by project name pattern

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The location of {{vcvarsall.bat}} has changed in Visual Studio 2017. We hard code this in {{devenvrunner.bat}} so the builds are not running.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install Visual Studio 2017 with C++ tools
# Run a Visual Studio build task

h3. Expected Results
The build find {{vcvarsall.bat}} and sets all the required variables
h3. Actual Results
The build cannot find the file, so the build is unable to run.

h3.Workaround
Update the {{devenvrunner.bat}} to have the path be:
{code}call "%BAM_VS_HOME%\VC\Auxiliary\Build\vcvarsall.bat" %BAM_VS_ARCH%{code}
fields.summary: Update bamboo-dotnet-plugin vcvarsall.bat path in devenvrunner.bat for VisualStudio 2017

h3. Summary

h3.Workaround
